{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3251194,"name":"Jack","username":"J.F","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-11-09T09:08:27.246Z","cooked":"

My senior always tell us to use as big ratio as possible to power a system such as arm (he set 200:1 of the ratio of arm), but I don’t agree his point because speed is also important. However, I don’t have any data to convince him because I am not good at physics, just can tell him that many team didn’t do that.

Therefore, I wonder whether there is a easy way to calculate or a calculator so that I just need to key in some constant.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-11-09T09:08:27.246Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":105,"reads":242,"readers_count":241,"score":588.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":443946,"topic_slug":"any-way-to-calculate-torque-of-system","display_username":"Jack","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59611,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/any-way-to-calculate-torque-of-system/443946/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3251198,"name":"Bryce Hanson","username":"BryceHanson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brycehanson/{size}/159972_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-09T10:23:58.842Z","cooked":"

There’s a lot of great tools for this in FRC. I would recommend ReCalc specifically, which will help you figure out the math behind what you’re trying to do (it also has docs linked to each calculator that you can read through). The short answer is that both speed and torque are important, so you’re both right. Often, teams will set a maximum acceptable duration for an arm to move (let’s say 1 second to move 180*), and then use a calculator to figure out what gear ratio and motor power they need to throw at the problem to safely do that without damaging any of the components involved.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-11-09T10:23:58.842Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":153.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":443946,"topic_slug":"any-way-to-calculate-torque-of-system","display_username":"Bryce Hanson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.reca.lc/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ReCalc","clicks":50}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31172,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"125M/7525M | MC/GA "},"post_url":"/t/any-way-to-calculate-torque-of-system/443946/2","custom_user_title":"125M/7525M | MC/GA ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3251201,"name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","username":"AriMB","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-09T10:59:33.203Z","cooked":"

Unfortunately, it isn’t as easy as typing in one number and getting the result. Fortunately, as @BryceHanson said, there are lots of tools out there to help you.

I’ll recommend the calculator that I developed, ambcalc.com. There are lots of useful tools there, but the one you’re looking for is the Mechanism Calculator. At the bottom is examples including designing an arm, but I’ll give a brief walkthrough here. There are a few properties of the system you have to enter: the type and number of motors you’re using, the force acting on the arm, and the radius at which that force is applied (i.e. the length of the arm). From there, you get a graph showing how changing the gear ratio changes the properties of the system (free and loaded speeds, current draw, stall voltage, etc). You can choose to set any one of those values, and see how that affects the rest. Some things you want to look out for are the free and loaded speeds of the arm (make sure it isn’t too slow or too fast to be uncontrolable), the current draw (to make sure you won’t trip breakers), and the stall voltage (to make sure you won’t burn the motor when holding in place for a long time). Once you find the right point on the graph for your use case, you will have the ratio you need for the mechanism.

Thanks for your recommendation, but I have some questions after trying.

image1170×2532 347 KB

Can you give me an example about ratio? It not like what I think it is.
What is the iteration time mean?
Are the KG, KV, and KA for Falcon?

Thanks for your recommendation, too.

image1170×2532 988 KB

I just test that, and wonder whether you will recommend me to set a little bigger ratio to sure the torque is enough. If is, what number should I add?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-11-09T11:16:32.552Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":191,"readers_count":190,"score":73.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":443946,"topic_slug":"any-way-to-calculate-torque-of-system","display_username":"Jack","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/0/7/07601549d539aeb03596476562a9a452b7edccc1.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":25012,"username":"AriMB","name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59611,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/any-way-to-calculate-torque-of-system/443946/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3251204,"name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","username":"AriMB","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-09T11:26:34.246Z","cooked":"

It looks like you’ll want a higher ratio, since your Current Per Motor is 105 Amps which is too high. A safe value there would be around 40 Amps, which is the amount the breakers are rated for. You could maybe go up to 50 Amps since it’s only running for a second or two at a time. You also want to check the Stall Voltage, which is the amount of voltage you need to give the motor to hold the arm in place against gravity. You want this to be in the safe range for the motor for the duration of the match, which for a NEO is anything below around 4.5 Volts.
